title: What will be the daily closing spot price of Brent crude oil (USD per barrel) on 10 November 2017, according to the U.S. EIA?
preds: Last trade reported as 63.82 on 9 Nov at 1900 hrs. https://www.reuters.com/finance/commodities/energy https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/CO1:COM The daily fluctuation yesterday was 63.71 to 63.86, and it's been above 63.40 this whole week so far.
35.88 today. Held steady for several days. No reason to believe it will change.
Passage of Time (Last day):  Probabilities of a 1 day drop that would cross the $63.41 from $63.98 = 28.5%
Prices have been on the rise due to geopolitical uncertainty in Saudi Arabia, decreased crude supplies reported at pipeline hubs, and increased hedging is driving prices up.
Prices are rising again, and $63.40 looks it’s hardening as a support level.

I've been trying to figure out why the price EIA reports never seems to square up with the price anyone else shows.  I've been exchanging emails & phone calls with them all morning.  It seems to boil down to this:  the prices we can see when we do google searches are all futures prices.  The price EIA quotes is one they get from Reuters through their subscription. Today, EIA reports $63.96.   Futures traders are showing prices today from $63.26 to $64.25, and at $64.07 right  now.
Today I'm following the fox, but suspecting the hedgehogs may beat me. A shout out to @jtrommel.

Because it's been going up, time to go down.
Updating based on additional information and expectation of increased prices following Saudi upheaval.
Oil prices are volatile, but given we have 3 days left, the fluctuations should be close to where the price is now.
With the recent events in Saudi Arabia and the alleged consolidation of power from Muhammad bin Salman, crude oil prices spiked.

The following is on everybody's thoughts today: Crude oil prices surged to the highest level since July 2015 as a purge of the Saudi elite stoked supply disruption fears. In a move reportedly engineered by ascendant Crown Price Mohammed bin Salman, security forces rounded up members of the royal family, ministers, billionaires and top officials almost immediately after King Salman announced a sweeping anti-corruption initiative. Today at 64.23 The Saudi state now has a strong preference for $70 rather than $50 oil (even more pronounced than before) which means that policies may tolerate an increased risk of overshooting rather than undershooting.
Given the delicate political and economic context, Saudi Arabia will probably prefer to risk tightening the oil market too much and see prices hit $70, rather than risk letting them slip back to $50. (Thanks to @dsarin )

Current price is 64.23 The jump in prices is driven by geopolitics centered around actions taken in or by Saudi Arabia, rather than fundamentals.  Profit takers may become active in the next few days and bring the price down below $63.40, but there are still four days to monitor movements. Staying high for now.

As of 6 November 2017, Brent crude oil is at 64.27 (http://www.nasdaq.com/markets/crude-oil-brent.aspx). This is a two-year high triggered by events in Saudia Arabia, where the crown prince is pushing a purge to basically take out remaining opposition (many are part of the royal family). It's officially referred to as a anti-corruption campaign. These events tend to worry observers and investors and lead to upticks in commodity prices (this case oil), as regime stability could be compromised if there's a power struggle. Yet usually prices tend to recover and stabilise, but that is unlikely to happen by 10 Nov.

Backing off slightly from the top bucket. OPEC World Oil Outlook report becomes public/non-embargoed (whatever that means) at 8:30 a.m. New York time tomorrow, if I'm counting correctly per the following link.

Pricing & Timing update... I have the current price at >$64.  Unless there is an immediate pull back, Seems to that the <$60 is now out of the realm of possibility with only a modest hope for <$63.50.

momentum might be sustainable through to Friday.
I'm pegging my prediction to the Front month future price currently 62.07
The weekend’s events in the Middle East pretty well blew out the $63 resistance level. Plenty of upside pressure over the next four days I think.

Saudi are threatening war, because of missile attack. It doesn't matter if this is all talk, as this lack of stability will allow prices to float upwards for a bit. Expect price to go above 70 until situation resolves itself.
No one knew that the arrests in KSA would lead to higher prices but today it did to above 64. Will watch tomorrow for more difinitive answer.

1) fear:  of political instability in KSA, and how this might impact supply
2) KSA's increased need to keep the price high:  economic woes at a time of social & political upheaval could be catastrophic. As of this morning it is $61.42 on EIA, which makes it closer to the next bin down, but it has been trading in the $63.40+ range today in the east, so the price posted on 11/7 may show a significant increase. I may increase my forecast for $63.40 later today, depending on how it trades today.

Price as at 5 Nov is $62.05. A best guess is to forecast tomorrow's price as equal to today's. so this is the most likely outcome. However, cumulative five day variations can be more than a $1.35 'gain' and at lower probability greater than a $1.95 'loss'.
upward trend from spot most appropriate for short term forecast

last month's trend is bullish. there's a support between 60 and 61 dollars. below that, there's a number of supports between 56 and 58. i think the positive trend will continue, but should a correction occur, the price is likely to stay above the $56 mark. only a major piece of bad news could impact the price significately, in the next 5 days.

Following @dsarin on the basis of his record forecasting similar questions. Most significantly, right now he is #2 on the HFC leaderboard with 21 questions scored; #15 CFA Challenge with 9 questions scored; and #4 on Arab Strategy Forum, with 15 questions scored.
Forecast based on data available on 2017-11-03.
Based on YTD trends and possible new $63 resistance level.
I developed this forecast by fitting an ARIMA model to all historical price data available via the EIA API. Will update as new data becomes available.

It is at about 61 right now. Saudi Arabia is sticking to OPEC cut back. Both Saudi Arabia and Russia need high price. US might overcome this with Shale production next year but in short-term prices will remain high.
On the assumption of OPEC production cuts. Note that US oil production doesn't factor at all.

Well in the next week OPEC will release its annual World Oil Outlook in the lead up to its big meeting at the end of the month. With that in mind I don't expect oil prices to move very much in response as the global oil market is well understood and more influenced by American shale producers than OPEC production decisions.

Why in the world does anyone want to know that the price will be in 10 days? What's magic/important about November 10th? What will be happening that day? Or just before it? Does anyone have any idea?  When will OPEC meet next? Are there any meetings scheduled between the leaders of big oil producers (Venezuela, Nigeria, Iran, Russia, Saudi Arabia, the Kurds?) and energy buyers like China? India?  What's this REALLY about!!!

I could not find any auto-correlation in the results (that is, past price movements do not reasonably predict future price movements).  As such, I was forced to simply apply a normal distribution: An estimated of 10-day standard deviation: $3.40 per Barrel per week.
Estimated Median: $60.80 Hope this helps.
